Description: T cells directly kill infected and tumor cells primarily within barrier and non-lymphoid tissues. To prevent reinfection, effector T cells differentiate into long-lived memory T cells that either recirculate or establish long-lived immune protection throughout the body as tissue-resident memory T cells. Tissue-resident memory T cells constitute a large portion of the T cell memory population, can remain lodged in tissues for the lifetime of the organism, and offer a rapid and potent first line of defense due to their enhanced effector functions and proximity to sites of reinfection. Thus, promoting tissue-resident memory T cell formation can improve protection from viral and bacterial infections and even tumor growth. This session will cover what is known about the function and differentiation of tissue-resident memory T cells and the current understanding of their role in anti-tumor immunity.
Title: T Resident Memory Cells
